title: 108_s997
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. It provides water to many in New Mexico and should be maintained to protect endangered species and the river flow while enhancing public access. The Corps of Engineers' mission includes environmental restoration, and they should aim to reestablish hydrologic connections in the area. The Corps of Engineers should reestablish the hydrologic connection between the Middle Rio Grande and the Middle Rio Grande bosque to ensure healthy vegetation growth. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "critical restoration project" as a project that will provide immediate ecosystem restoration benefits, "Middle Rio Grande" as a portion of the Rio Grande in New Mexico, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Army. The Secretary will carry out critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande based on feasibility studies and existing plans. Local participation from public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed is required. Cost-sharing agreements must be established before project implementation. The Middle Rio Grande Endangered Species Act Collaborative Program and the Bosque Improvement Group of the Middle Rio Grande Bosque Initiative are key initiatives. Cost-sharing agreements with non-Federal interests are required for critical restoration projects, including payment of 25% of total costs, providing necessary land and materials, and covering operation and maintenance costs. The critical restoration project costs incurred after the enactment of this Act must be covered by non-Federal interests. Recreational features in the project should not exceed 30% of the total cost, with non-Federal interests responsible for any additional costs. Non-Federal interests will receive credit for their contributions. The non-Federal interests are responsible for covering restoration project costs exceeding the specified amount. They will receive credit for their contributions towards design or construction activities integral to the project. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
